title: Sort node collection
user_story:
As an API consumer\
I want to be able to request NODE collections as sorted lists\
So I can find information faster and with fewer requests
description:
When requesting a node collection the user should be able to provide sorting parameters, so the data is returned in the most useful form. E.g. sorting BRANDS by its *founded date* to quickly find all nodes where this information is missing. Or sorting a CAR MODEL collection by *max. power* to create a top-10 list of the fastest cars. The alternative for the user would be to download each and every node and then sort them with a separate tool. That option would be much worse in respect to usability, user acceptance and performance.

# Specification

* The user can attach the parameter `sort_by_property` to every “get all nodes of node type” request, e.g. `GET /brands?sort_by_property=name`.
* All “official“ properties of the node type are available to be sorted by. Those can be user-provided properties (e.g. name), meta properties (e.g. id or created\_at), generated properties (e.g. slugs), calculated properties (e.g. normalized top speed) or acquired properties (image data from flickr). They are “official“ when they are documented in the OpenAPI specification.
* With the parameter `sort_direction` the user can switch between the two options `asc` and `desc` (ascending and descending).
* By default the returned collection is sorted by ID.
* By default the returned collection is sorted ascending. 
* Both parameters are optional. They can be omitted, used together or alone.
* Valid requests return a collection of nodes. → Status code `200`
* There is no change to the number of returned nodes. The rules defined in <https://dennis-gerike.atlassian.net/browse/MCA-558>  and <https://dennis-gerike.atlassian.net/browse/MCA-369>  still apply. → TLDR: Empty collections and empty pages materialize as an empty list and status code `200`
* Invalid requests are rejected. → Status code `400`
* Invalid cases are:
  * the `sort_direction` is anything other than `asc` or `desc` or empty
  * the `sort_by_property` value is a property that is NOT specified for the node type
* The data structure of the returned node collection does not change in any way or form.

# Scope & Limits

* Meta information is not returned in this iteration (sort property, sort direction, next page, etc.)
